items: Use input() to collect data from users
Convert input strings to numbers with int() or float()

sections.heading: Why input matters
paragraphs: Up until now, your programs just run and display output. Real programs often need interaction, like login prompts, game player info, or calculator inputs. To make programs interactive, we use input().

sections.heading: The input() function
paragraphs: input() lets the program pause and wait for the user to type something. Whatever the user types is stored as a string (text) by default.
Syntax: variable_name = input("Message shown to the user: ")

sections.heading: Input is always a string
paragraphs: Even if the user types a number, Python treats it as text. This matters when doing math with input.

sections.heading: Converting input
paragraphs: To do math with numbers entered by users, convert the input using int() or float().

questions.prompt: Which function is used to get input from a user?
What data type is returned by input() by default?
You want to add two numbers entered by the user. Which code is correct?
choices:
x = input("Enter first: ")
y = input("Enter second: ")
print(x + y)

x = int(input("Enter first: "))
y = int(input("Enter second: "))
print(x + y)

x = str(input("Enter first: "))
y = str(input("Enter second: "))
print(x + y)

x = input("Enter first: ")
y = input("Enter second: ")
print(int(x) + int(y))
